theme.title: The eighth note and its rest
theme.para: The next figure we are going to study is the eighth note (also called 'quaver' in British English) and its rest. Their symbols are shown in the followig score, and are like a quarter note with a flag added to its stem; they are usually drawn beamed:

score.music: (Metrica 2 4 noVisible) (n a4 c)(n f4 c)(n c4 c g+)(n g4 c g-)(n g4 c g+)(n c5 c g-)(s c)(Barra Final))

theme.para: One quarter note equals two eighth notes and one quarter rest equals two eighth rests. So in time 2/4 an eighth note or rest gets half a beats, and, therefore, there are two eighth notes in a beat. So in 2/4 they are usually drawn beamed, occupying a beat:

score.music: (metrica 2 4) (n * n)(n * c)(n * c)(barra Simple) (n * n)(n * c g+)(n * c g-)(barra Simple) (n * n)(n * c)(s c)(barra Final)

part.title: Lesson and note the differences
part.para: Lesson each measure and note how the new introduced pattern appears:

score.music: (metrica 2 4) (n * n)(n * c)(n * c)(barra Simple) (n * n)(n * c g+)(n * c g-) (n * c)(s c)(s c)(n * c)(barra Final)
